constructors.doc: Creates a new entry with the specified text buffer.
constructors.name: new_with_buffer

doc:
The widget is a single line text entry widget. A fairly large set of key bindings are supported by default. If the entered text is longer than the allocation of the widget, the widget will scroll so that the cursor position is visible.

When using an entry for passwords and other sensitive information, it can be put into “password mode” using . In this mode, entered text is displayed using a “invisible” character. By default, GTK+ picks the best invisible character that is available in the current font, but it can be changed with . Since 2.16, GTK+ displays a warning when Caps Lock or input methods might interfere with entering text in a password entry. The warning can be turned off with the property.

Since 2.16, GtkEntry has the ability to display progress or activity information behind the text. To make an entry display such information, use or .

Additionally, GtkEntry can show icons at either side of the entry. These icons can be activatable by clicking, can be set up as drag source and can have tooltips. To add an icon, use or one of the various other functions that set an icon from a stock id, an icon name or a pixbuf. To trigger an action when the user clicks an icon, connect to the signal. To allow DND operations from an icon, use . To set a tooltip on an icon, use or the corresponding function for markup.

Note that functionality or information that is only available by clicking on an icon in an entry may not be accessible at all to users which are not able to use a mouse or other pointing device. It is therefore recommended that any such functionality should also be available by other means, e.g. via the context menu of the entry.

methods.doc: Retrieves the value set by .
methods.name: get_activates_default

methods.doc: Gets the value set by .
methods.name: get_alignment

methods.doc: Gets the attribute list that was set on the entry using , if any.
methods.name: get_attributes

methods.doc: Get the object which holds the text for this widget.
methods.name: get_buffer

methods.doc: Returns the auxiliary completion object currently in use by entry.
methods.name: get_completion

methods.doc:
Returns the index of the icon which is the source of the current DND operation, or -1.

This function is meant to be used in a callback.
methods.name: get_current_icon_drag_source

methods.doc: Retrieves the horizontal cursor adjustment for the entry. See .
methods.name: get_cursor_hadjustment

methods.doc: Gets the value set by .
methods.name: get_has_frame

methods.doc: Returns whether the icon is activatable.
methods.name: get_icon_activatable

methods.doc:
Gets the area where entry’s icon at icon_pos is drawn. This function is useful when drawing something to the entry in a draw callback.

If the entry is not realized or has no icon at the given position, icon_area is filled with zeros.

See also
methods.name: get_icon_area

methods.doc: Finds the icon at the given position and return its index. The position’s coordinates are relative to the entry’s top left corner. If x, y doesn’t lie inside an icon, -1 is returned. This function is intended for use in a signal handler.
methods.name: get_icon_at_pos

methods.doc: Retrieves the Gio.Icon used for the icon, or null if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g., by stock, pixbuf, or icon name).
methods.name: get_icon_gicon

methods.doc: Retrieves the icon name used for the icon, or null if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g., by pixbuf, stock or gicon).
methods.name: get_icon_name

methods.doc:
Retrieves the image used for the icon.

Unlike the other methods of setting and getting icon data, this method will work regardless of whether the icon was set using a GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf, a Gio.Icon, a stock item, or an icon name.
methods.name: get_icon_pixbuf

methods.doc: Returns whether the icon appears sensitive or insensitive.
methods.name: get_icon_sensitive

methods.doc: Retrieves the stock id used for the icon, or null if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g., by pixbuf, icon name or gicon).
methods.name: get_icon_stock

methods.doc: Gets the type of representation being used by the icon to store image data. If the icon has no image data, the return value will be .empty.
methods.name: get_icon_storage_type

methods.doc: Gets the contents of the tooltip on the icon at the specified position in entry.
methods.name: get_icon_tooltip_markup

methods.doc: Gets the contents of the tooltip on the icon at the specified position in entry.
methods.name: get_icon_tooltip_text

methods.doc: This function returns the entry’s property. See for more information.
methods.name: get_inner_border

methods.doc: Gets the value of the property.
methods.name: get_input_hints

methods.doc: Gets the value of the property.
methods.name: get_input_purpose

methods.doc: Retrieves the character displayed in place of the real characters for entries with visibility set to false. See .
methods.name: get_invisible_char

methods.doc:
Gets the Pango.Layout used to display the entry. The layout is useful to e.g. convert text positions to pixel positions, in combination with . The returned layout is owned by the entry and must not be modified or freed by the caller.

Keep in mind that the layout text may contain a preedit string, so and are needed to convert byte indices in the layout to byte indices in the entry contents.
methods.name: get_layout

methods.doc:
Obtains the position of the Pango.Layout used to render text in the entry, in widget coordinates. Useful if you want to line up the text in an entry with some other text, e.g. when using the entry to implement editable cells in a sheet widget.

Also useful to convert mouse events into coordinates inside the Pango.Layout, e.g. to take some action if some part of the entry text is clicked.

Note that as the user scrolls around in the entry the offsets will change; you’ll need to connect to the “notify::scroll-offset” signal to track this. Remember when using the Pango.Layout functions you need to convert to and from pixels using PANGO_PIXELS() or #PANGO_SCALE.

Keep in mind that the layout text may contain a preedit string, so and are needed to convert byte indices in the layout to byte indices in the entry contents.
methods.name: get_layout_offsets

methods.doc:
Retrieves the maximum allowed length of the text in entry. See .

This is equivalent to:

|[<!-- language="C" --> GtkEntryBuffer *buffer; buffer = gtk_entry_get_buffer (entry); gtk_entry_buffer_get_max_length (buffer); ]|
methods.name: get_max_length

methods.doc: Retrieves the desired maximum width of entry, in characters. See .
methods.name: get_max_width_chars

methods.doc: Gets the value set by .
methods.name: get_overwrite_mode

methods.doc: Retrieves the text that will be displayed when entry is empty and unfocused
methods.name: get_placeholder_text

methods.doc: Returns the current fraction of the task that’s been completed. See .
methods.name: get_progress_fraction

methods.doc: Retrieves the pulse step set with .
methods.name: get_progress_pulse_step

methods.doc: Gets the tabstops that were set on the entry using , if any.
methods.name: get_tabs

methods.doc:
Retrieves the contents of the entry widget. See also .

This is equivalent to:

|[<!-- language="C" --> GtkEntryBuffer *buffer; buffer = gtk_entry_get_buffer (entry); gtk_entry_buffer_get_text (buffer); ]|
methods.name: get_text

methods.doc:
Gets the area where the entry’s text is drawn. This function is useful when drawing something to the entry in a draw callback.

If the entry is not realized, text_area is filled with zeros.

See also .
methods.name: get_text_area

methods.doc:
Retrieves the current length of the text in entry.

This is equivalent to:

|[<!-- language="C" --> GtkEntryBuffer *buffer; buffer = gtk_entry_get_buffer (entry); gtk_entry_buffer_get_length (buffer); ]|
methods.name: get_text_length

methods.doc: Retrieves whether the text in entry is visible. See .
methods.name: get_visibility

methods.doc: Gets the value set by .
methods.name: get_width_chars

methods.doc:
Allow the input method to internally handle key press and release events. If this function returns true, then no further processing should be done for this key event. See .

Note that you are expected to call this function from your handler when overriding key event handling. This is needed in the case when you need to insert your own key handling between the input method and the default key event handling of the . See for an example of use.
methods.name: im_context_filter_keypress

methods.doc: Converts from a position in the entry contents (returned by ) to a position in the entry’s Pango.Layout (returned by , with text retrieved via Pango.Layout.prototype.get_text).
methods.name: layout_index_to_text_index

methods.doc: Indicates that some progress is made, but you don’t know how much. Causes the entry’s progress indicator to enter “activity mode,” where a block bounces back and forth. Each call to causes the block to move by a little bit (the amount of movement per pulse is determined by ).
methods.name: progress_pulse

methods.doc:
Reset the input method context of the entry if needed.

This can be necessary in the case where modifying the buffer would confuse on-going input method behavior.
methods.name: reset_im_context

methods.doc:
If setting is true, pressing Enter in the entry will activate the default widget for the window containing the entry. This usually means that the dialog box containing the entry will be closed, since the default widget is usually one of the dialog buttons.

(For experts: if setting is true, the entry calls on the window containing the entry, in the default handler for the signal.)
methods.name: set_activates_default

methods.doc: Sets the alignment for the contents of the entry. This controls the horizontal positioning of the contents when the displayed text is shorter than the width of the entry.
methods.name: set_alignment

methods.doc: Sets a Pango.AttrList; the attributes in the list are applied to the entry text.
methods.name: set_attributes

methods.doc: Set the object which holds the text for this widget.
methods.name: set_buffer

methods.doc: Sets completion to be the auxiliary completion object to use with entry. All further configuration of the completion mechanism is done on completion using the API. Completion is disabled if completion is set to null.
methods.name: set_completion

methods.doc:
Hooks up an adjustment to the cursor position in an entry, so that when the cursor is moved, the adjustment is scrolled to show that position. See for a typical way of obtaining the adjustment.

The adjustment has to be in pixel units and in the same coordinate system as the entry.
methods.name: set_cursor_hadjustment

methods.doc: Sets whether the entry has a beveled frame around it.
methods.name: set_has_frame

methods.doc: Sets whether the icon is activatable.
methods.name: set_icon_activatable

methods.doc:
Sets up the icon at the given position so that GTK+ will start a drag operation when the user clicks and drags the icon.

To handle the drag operation, you need to connect to the usual (or possibly ) signal, and use in your signal handler to find out if the drag was started from an icon.

By default, GTK+ uses the icon as the drag icon. You can use the signal to set a different icon. Note that you have to use g_signal_connect_after() to ensure that your signal handler gets executed after the default handler.
methods.name: set_icon_drag_source

methods.doc:
Sets the icon shown in the entry at the specified position from the current icon theme. If the icon isn’t known, a “broken image” icon will be displayed instead.

If icon is null, no icon will be shown in the specified position.
methods.name: set_icon_from_gicon

methods.doc:
Sets the icon shown in the entry at the specified position from the current icon theme.

If the icon name isn’t known, a “broken image” icon will be displayed instead.

If icon_name is null, no icon will be shown in the specified position.
methods.name: set_icon_from_icon_name

methods.doc:
Sets the icon shown in the specified position using a pixbuf.

If pixbuf is null, no icon will be shown in the specified position.
methods.name: set_icon_from_pixbuf

methods.doc:
Sets the icon shown in the entry at the specified position from a stock image.

If stock_id is null, no icon will be shown in the specified position.
methods.name: set_icon_from_stock

methods.doc: Sets the sensitivity for the specified icon.
methods.name: set_icon_sensitive

methods.doc:
Sets tooltip as the contents of the tooltip for the icon at the specified position. tooltip is assumed to be marked up with the [Pango text markup language][PangoMarkupFormat].

Use null for tooltip to remove an existing tooltip.

See also and .
methods.name: set_icon_tooltip_markup

methods.doc:
Sets tooltip as the contents of the tooltip for the icon at the specified position.

Use null for tooltip to remove an existing tooltip.

See also and .
methods.name: set_icon_tooltip_text

methods.doc:
Sets %entry’s inner-border property to border, or clears it if null is passed. The inner-border is the area around the entry’s text, but inside its frame.

If set, this property overrides the inner-border style property. Overriding the style-provided border is useful when you want to do in-place editing of some text in a canvas or list widget, where pixel-exact positioning of the entry is important.
methods.name: set_inner_border

methods.doc: Sets the property, which allows input methods to fine-tune their behaviour.
methods.name: set_input_hints

methods.doc: Sets the property which can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.
methods.name: set_input_purpose

methods.doc: Sets the character to use in place of the actual text when has been called to set text visibility to false. i.e. this is the character used in “password mode” to show the user how many characters have been typed. By default, GTK+ picks the best invisible char available in the current font. If you set the invisible char to 0, then the user will get no feedback at all; there will be no text on the screen as they type.
methods.name: set_invisible_char

methods.doc:
Sets the maximum allowed length of the contents of the widget. If the current contents are longer than the given length, then they will be truncated to fit.

This is equivalent to:

|[<!-- language="C" --> GtkEntryBuffer *buffer; buffer = gtk_entry_get_buffer (entry); gtk_entry_buffer_set_max_length (buffer, max); ]|
methods.name: set_max_length

methods.doc: Sets the desired maximum width in characters of entry.
methods.name: set_max_width_chars

methods.doc: Sets whether the text is overwritten when typing in the .
methods.name: set_overwrite_mode

methods.doc:
Sets text to be displayed in entry when it is empty and unfocused. This can be used to give a visual hint of the expected contents of the .

Note that since the placeholder text gets removed when the entry received focus, using this feature is a bit problematic if the entry is given the initial focus in a window. Sometimes this can be worked around by delaying the initial focus setting until the first key event arrives.
methods.name: set_placeholder_text

methods.doc: Causes the entry’s progress indicator to “fill in” the given fraction of the bar. The fraction should be between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive.
methods.name: set_progress_fraction

methods.doc: Sets the fraction of total entry width to move the progress bouncing block for each call to .
methods.name: set_progress_pulse_step

methods.doc: Sets a Pango.TabArray; the tabstops in the array are applied to the entry text.
methods.name: set_tabs

methods.doc:
Sets the text in the widget to the given value, replacing the current contents.

See .
methods.name: set_text

methods.doc:
Sets whether the contents of the entry are visible or not. When visibility is set to false, characters are displayed as the invisible char, and will also appear that way when the text in the entry widget is copied elsewhere.

By default, GTK+ picks the best invisible character available in the current font, but it can be changed with .

Note that you probably want to set to .password or .pin to inform input methods about the purpose of this entry, in addition to setting visibility to false.
methods.name: set_visibility

methods.doc: Changes the size request of the entry to be about the right size for n_chars characters. Note that it changes the size request, the size can still be affected by how you pack the widget into containers. If n_chars is -1, the size reverts to the default entry size.
methods.name: set_width_chars

methods.doc: Converts from a position in the entry’s Pango.Layout (returned by ) to a position in the entry contents (returned by ).
methods.name: text_index_to_layout_index

methods.doc: Unsets the invisible char previously set with . So that the default invisible char is used again.
methods.name: unset_invisible_char

name: Entry

properties.doc:
A list of Pango attributes to apply to the text of the entry.

This is mainly useful to change the size or weight of the text.
properties.name: attributes

properties.doc:
Whether password entries will show a warning when Caps Lock is on.

Note that the warning is shown using a secondary icon, and thus does not work if you are using the secondary icon position for some other purpose.
properties.name: caps-lock-warning

properties.doc: The auxiliary completion object to use with the entry.
properties.name: completion

properties.doc:
Which IM (input method) module should be used for this entry. See .

Setting this to a non-null value overrides the system-wide IM module setting. See the GtkSettings property.
properties.name: im-module

properties.doc: Sets the text area's border between the text and the frame.
properties.name: inner-border

properties.doc: Additional hints (beyond ) that allow input methods to fine-tune their behaviour.
properties.name: input-hints

properties.doc:
The purpose of this text field.

This property can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.

Note that setting the purpose to .password or .pin is independent from setting .
properties.name: input-purpose

properties.doc:
The invisible character is used when masking entry contents (in \"password mode\")"). When it is not explicitly set with the property, GTK+ determines the character to use from a list of possible candidates, depending on availability in the current font.

This style property allows the theme to prepend a character to the list of candidates.
properties.name: invisible-char

properties.doc: Whether the invisible char has been set for the .
properties.name: invisible-char-set

properties.doc: The desired maximum width of the entry, in characters. If this property is set to -1, the width will be calculated automatically.
properties.name: max-width-chars

properties.doc: If text is overwritten when typing in the .
properties.name: overwrite-mode

properties.doc: The text that will be displayed in the when it is empty and unfocused.
properties.name: placeholder-text

properties.doc: If :populate-all is true, the signal is also emitted for touch popups.
properties.name: populate-all

properties.doc:
Whether the primary icon is activatable.

GTK+ emits the and signals only on sensitive, activatable icons.

Sensitive, but non-activatable icons can be used for purely informational purposes.
properties.name: primary-icon-activatable

properties.doc: The Gio.Icon to use for the primary icon for the entry.
properties.name: primary-icon-gicon

properties.doc: The icon name to use for the primary icon for the entry.
properties.name: primary-icon-name

properties.doc: A pixbuf to use as the primary icon for the entry.
properties.name: primary-icon-pixbuf

properties.doc:
Whether the primary icon is sensitive.

An insensitive icon appears grayed out. GTK+ does not emit the and signals and does not allow DND from insensitive icons.

An icon should be set insensitive if the action that would trigger when clicked is currently not available.
properties.name: primary-icon-sensitive

properties.doc: The stock id to use for the primary icon for the entry.
properties.name: primary-icon-stock

properties.doc: The representation which is used for the primary icon of the entry.
properties.name: primary-icon-storage-type

properties.doc:
The contents of the tooltip on the primary icon, which is marked up with the [Pango text markup language][PangoMarkupFormat].

Also see .
properties.name: primary-icon-tooltip-markup

properties.doc:
The contents of the tooltip on the primary icon.

Also see .
properties.name: primary-icon-tooltip-text

properties.doc: The current fraction of the task that's been completed.
properties.name: progress-fraction

properties.doc: The fraction of total entry width to move the progress bouncing block for each call to .
properties.name: progress-pulse-step

properties.doc:
Whether the secondary icon is activatable.

GTK+ emits the and signals only on sensitive, activatable icons.

Sensitive, but non-activatable icons can be used for purely informational purposes.
properties.name: secondary-icon-activatable

properties.doc: The Gio.Icon to use for the secondary icon for the entry.
properties.name: secondary-icon-gicon

properties.doc: The icon name to use for the secondary icon for the entry.
properties.name: secondary-icon-name

properties.doc: An pixbuf to use as the secondary icon for the entry.
properties.name: secondary-icon-pixbuf

properties.doc:
Whether the secondary icon is sensitive.

An insensitive icon appears grayed out. GTK+ does not emit the and signals and does not allow DND from insensitive icons.

An icon should be set insensitive if the action that would trigger when clicked is currently not available.
properties.name: secondary-icon-sensitive

properties.doc: The stock id to use for the secondary icon for the entry.
properties.name: secondary-icon-stock

properties.doc: The representation which is used for the secondary icon of the entry.
properties.name: secondary-icon-storage-type

properties.doc:
The contents of the tooltip on the secondary icon, which is marked up with the [Pango text markup language][PangoMarkupFormat].

Also see .
properties.name: secondary-icon-tooltip-markup

properties.doc:
The contents of the tooltip on the secondary icon.

Also see .
properties.name: secondary-icon-tooltip-text

properties.doc: Which kind of shadow to draw around the entry when is set to true.
properties.name: shadow-type

properties.doc: The length of the text in the .
properties.name: text-length

properties.doc: When true, pasted multi-line text is truncated to the first line.
properties.name: truncate-multiline

properties.doc: The horizontal alignment, from 0 (left) to 1 (right). Reversed for RTL layouts.
properties.name: xalign

signals.doc:
The ::activate signal is emitted when the user hits the Enter key.

While this signal is used as a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal], it is also commonly used by applications to intercept activation of entries.

The default bindings for this signal are all forms of the Enter key.
signals.name: activate

signals.doc:
The ::backspace signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.

The default bindings for this signal are Backspace and Shift-Backspace.
signals.name: backspace

signals.doc:
The ::copy-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted to copy the selection to the clipboard.

The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-c and Ctrl-Insert.
signals.name: copy-clipboard

signals.doc:
The ::cut-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted to cut the selection to the clipboard.

The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-x and Shift-Delete.
signals.name: cut-clipboard

signals.doc:
The ::delete-from-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user initiates a text deletion.

If the type is .chars, GTK+ deletes the selection if there is one, otherwise it deletes the requested number of characters.

The default bindings for this signal are Delete for deleting a character and Ctrl-Delete for deleting a word.
signals.name: delete-from-cursor

signals.doc: The ::icon-press signal is emitted when an activatable icon is clicked.
signals.name: icon-press

signals.doc: The ::icon-release signal is emitted on the button release from a mouse click over an activatable icon.
signals.name: icon-release

signals.doc:
The ::insert-at-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user initiates the insertion of a fixed string at the cursor.

This signal has no default bindings.
signals.name: insert-at-cursor

signals.doc:
The ::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement. If the cursor is not visible in @entry, this signal causes the viewport to be moved instead.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control the cursor programmatically.

The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifer does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. - Arrow keys move by individual characters/lines - Ctrl-arrow key combinations move by words/paragraphs - Home/End keys move to the ends of the buffer
signals.name: move-cursor

signals.doc:
The ::paste-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted to paste the contents of the clipboard into the text view.

The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-v and Shift-Insert.
signals.name: paste-clipboard

signals.doc:
The ::populate-popup signal gets emitted before showing the context menu of the entry.

If you need to add items to the context menu, connect to this signal and append your items to the @widget, which will be a in this case.

If is true, this signal will also be emitted to populate touch popups. In this case, @widget will be a different container, e.g. a . The signal handler should not make assumptions about the type of @widget.
signals.name: populate-popup

signals.doc: If an input method is used, the typed text will not immediately be committed to the buffer. So if you are interested in the text, connect to this signal.
signals.name: preedit-changed

signals.doc:
The ::toggle-overwrite signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted to toggle the overwrite mode of the entry.

The default bindings for this signal is Insert.
signals.name: toggle-overwrite
